title: Rwanda: Kigali Car-Free Zone a Great Idea but for the Hurried Introduction
text:
Kenya: Craftsman Assembles Vehicles From Scrap 
Car-free days, on the other hand, discourage the use of private vehicles while encouraging walking or use of public transportation. 
For this to be implemented successfully, the street should be well-planned for road closure and various activities should be set up to attract people to walk on the street. 
People will learn about alternative ways of using the streets and recognise the problems of car use -- used up fossil energy, air and noise pollution. 
Thus car-free day persuades people to think about the impact of their transportation behaviour on the environment. It can play a great role in shaping the transportation policies of a country. 
But experiences from elsewhere around the world show that successful implementation of car-free zone takes time and requires adequate planning. 
Yet Kigali City Council hastily implemented car free zone without making adequate preparations such as ensuring that public transport is efficient. As it is today, Kigali city still has an inefficient public transport system. 
Indeed, this inadequate preparation has only served to undermine what would otherwise be a good move. Already, the private sector -- starting with business owners on the car-free zone -- has raised a red flag over losing customers. 
Rather than beginning with streets that have thriving businesses, the City of Kigali should consider roads passing through administrative parts of the city or consider turning redundant green zones in the city into public parks. 
Turning roads into car-free zones has joined a growing list of hurriedly implemented policies. Kigali has in the past been accused of hurriedly expropriating people to pave way for development projects which later don't even take off. 
The country's development aspirations should go hand in hand with the needs of the people. Sustainable development is inclusive of the people and encompasses their interests. Rwanda
